4427880/4353914/4444348.title: A Story
4427880/4353914/4444348.text:
(continued from previous page)
sent the preacher off and there was never a preacher in Leakfafinne since.



There was once a minister living within a few miles of Dean Swift's and his name was Parker. The minister had a boy and also a dog. The dog was very old, he was both blind, and deaf and could not bark. The minister told his boy to hang the dog. The boy got a rope and he put it round the dog's neck. He was going away to hang the dog
(continues on next page)

4428114/4379455/4465357.title: Scéal
4428114/4379455/4465357.text:
(continued from previous page)
nuair a d'fhéach sí isteach ann bhí sé lán de prátaí. Ní raibh sí boicht as san amach. Do bhí iongantais ar gach aoinne a ionnaic cad a bhí tar éis tuitim amach.



Fadó chuaidh Dian Swift isteach go dtí tig Ósca do bhí lóistín uaidh sa tig agus ní raibh acht aon leabaidh fágtha aige an bhfear a bhí sa tig. Sa leabaidh san do bhí an fear oibre ina codhladh. Dubhairt an fear le Dian Swift dul a codhladh leis. Chuaidh an fear oibre síos go dtí bun na leabthan agus chuaidh Dian Swift ar bhárr na leabthn.Nuair a d'éirigheadar ar maidin d'fhiarfruig ceann acu de'n ceann eile. Cionus a chodhal sé aige na gcose an oidhche roimhe sin agus d'fhiafruigh an fear ósta díobh cionnas a bhíodar tar-éis na h-oidhche agus dubhraidear go raibheadhar go maith.



Bhí fear ann fadó agus bhíodh sé ag obair gach aon lá. Bhíodh sé an-dhéanach air nuair a bhíodh sé a teacht abhaile istoidhche. Oidhche amháin nuair a bhí sé ag dul abhaile treasna na páirceanna chonnaic sé fear mór dubh agus do bhí fiacla móra bána aige. Do bhí an
(continues on next page)

4713236/4710140/4744265.title: A Humorous Story
4713236/4710140/4744265.text: A very clever man lived in Ireland long ago by the name of Dean Swift. This man had a servant whom the people though was a fool, but they were mistaken.This day the Dean was invited to a great dinner, so he carried the servant with him. They came on horse-back and when they had arrived, the servant took the horse into the stable, where there were several other horses. They went into the dining room, but some few others remained outside. While all the others were inside, they were laughing at the strange servant. After dinner had been over, the Dean ordered the servant to look, after the horses.When he arrived at the stable-door he saw the two ears cut off his own horse. He knew them what the joking was about, so he cut the sides of every other horse in the stable. Then then went in. "Well said he I'm a long time in this world but never yet did I see such a queer thing. "Your horses ate the ears of my horse, and then they burst their sides laughing.

4742156/4740675/4782753.title: Celbridge Abbey
4742156/4740675/4782753.text: Celbridge Abbey Celbridge Abbey, was built in the 13th Century, and so it is the oldest inhabited house in Co. Kildare. It became the property of Mr. Van Homreigh, and so it was the home of dean Swifts Venessa.Afterwards the home of Henry Grattan, who got "Free Trade" for Ireland in the year 1782, and later on the home of his son.Teresa Mackey(adress given before)Information given by,Mr. J. Boyle (same address)

4769984/4764181/4933086.title: Dean Swift and the Ram of Gorey
4769984/4764181/4933086.text: Dean Swift while on a visit to Gorey in Wexford,was one day walking along the road,At a sharp bend in the road he was knocked in the ditch by a carriage driven and owned by a local landlord knick named the "Ram of Gorey," The "Ram" asked him who he was, The Dean answered; "I am the great Dean Swift, Englands pride and Irelands glory, who was knocked in the ditch, by the Ram of Gorey,

5044806/5040322/5084777.title: A Funny Story
5044806/5040322/5084777.text: There once lived in Ireland a Clergyman called Dean Swift, who was Dean of St Patricks, Dublin.  This Clergyman was supposed to always have a servant noted for his humour and the story is told that his coachman got the opportunity of eating the leg of a cooked goose.  When the Dean missed the limb he wanted to know what had happened and he got the reply that the fowl had only one leg.  When driving along the road the next day which was very cold a flock of geese were all standing on one leg.  The coachman drew the master's attention but the Dean said "hush' and immediately all the geese put down the other leg.  "Now." said the clergyman. "Oh yes" said the servant. "but you didn't say "hush" to the one that was cooked."

5070799/5065124/5096454.title: A Local Story
5070799/5065124/5096454.text: One day while Dean Swift was living at Quilca a great thunder storm came on. Sometime during the storm a man and a woman came to the door of the house and asked for shelter. They were admitted and during their stay they told the Dean that they were to be married on that morning but that  they were late know. The dean in order to save them great trouble said he would marry them. They went outside then and the Dean carried out the ceremony and then composed this verse. Beneath this tree in wintry weather,I join this man and woman together,And none but the Who rules the thunder,Will part this man and woman asunder.

5070799/5065130/5096512.title: Local History
5070799/5065130/5096512.text: Dean Swift used to come to Quilca to spend the Summer months there, and at the approach of Winter he would return to Dublin One particular Winter while he was in Dublin, Richard Brinsley Sheridan built an island in Quilca Lake, by bringing clay, and mud, and stones out in boats to a shallow place in the middle of the lake. The following Summer the Dean returned as usual, and Richard Brinsley Sheridan told him that the island was there one morning when he went out and that it must have been the fairies that built it. Dean Swift was ever afterwards afraid to go out near that part of the lake as he believed the island was enchanted.

5008916/4966455/5106962.title: Dean Swift
5008916/4966455/5106962.text: Dean Swift officiated in Rathbeggan Church which is now in ruins, and while doing so lives at a place called the Woodlands opposite the Flathouse.This house had twisted chimneys, and only a portion of it now stands.The Protestant clergyman then lived in a house part of  is standing at the end of the lane going to the Wilkinson's farmyard.Mr Davidson was the last clergyman to live there.Got fromRevd. Mr. ClenaghanBatterstown.Co. MeathThe Rectory in Batterstown was attacked by Croppies in ('98) and the then Rector sued for compensation.

4921700/4891270/5180969.title: Scéal
4921700/4891270/5180969.text: Do bhí Ár Slánuightheóir agus an Mhaighdean Mhuire ar a dtoreadh ag na Iúbhdaidhig. Ghabhadar thar páirc 'na raibh daoine ag cur coirce agus dúbhradar leis na daoine nár gádh dhóibh insinnt d'aoinne go rabhadar annso. Amáireach a bhí chúghainn ghaibh na Iúbhdaidhig cun na páirce ceudhna agus bhí na daoine ag baint an choirce seo d'fhiafruigheadar dos na daoine an bhfeacadar aon bheirt ag gabháil thar bhrágaid. Níor labhair aoinne focal ach bhí seanduine ann is dúbhairt sé go bhfeacadar iad an lá a bhííodar ag baint an choirce. Dúbhradar na Iúdaidhig nárbh aon mhaith é sin mar bhí leath bliadhain imthighe o shoin.Sar a raibh uain acu a thuille do rádh labhair daradaol is dúbhairt sé"Indé indé do cuireadh an gort."
